sentence: The Haskell type system has a number of features which all exist in other languages , but are rarely combined within a single , consistent language :

sentence: it is a sound , static type system , meaning that a number of errors are guaranteed not to happen at runtime without needing runtime type checks ( this is also the case in Caml , SML and almost the case in Java , but not in , say , Lisp , Python , C , or C++ ) ;
tag_sequence: O O O O O B-Data_Type O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O B-Language O O B-Language O O

sentence: it peforms static type reconstruction , meaning that the programmer does n't need to write types unless he wants to , the compiler will reconstruct them on its own ( this is also the case in Caml and SML , but not in Java or C ) ;
tag_sequence: O O B-Data_Type O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Application O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O

sentence: it supports impredicative polymorphism ( type variables ) , even at higher kinds ( unlike Caml and SML , or any other production-ready language known to me ) ;
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: it has good support for overloading ( type classes ) ( unlike Caml and SML ) .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O

sentence: Whether any of those make Haskell a better language is open to discussion — for example , while I happen to like type classes a lot , I know quite a few Caml programmers who strongly dislike overloading and prefer to use the module system .
tag_sequence: O O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: On the other hand , the Haskell type system lacks a few features that other languages support elegantly :
tag_sequence: O O O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: it has no support for runtime dispatch ( unlike Java , Lisp , and Julia ) ;
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O O B-Language O O

sentence: it has no support for existential types and GADTs ( these are both GHC extensions ) ;
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: it has no support for dependent types ( unlike Coq , Agda and Idris ) .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O B-Language O B-Language O B-Language O O

sentence: Again , whether any of these are desirable features in a general-purpose programming language is open to discussion .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: One major difference between Haskell 's type system and that of most OO languages is that the ability for a function to have side effects is represented by a data type ( a monad such as IO ) .
tag_sequence: O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Type O O B-Data_Type O O

sentence: This allows you to write pure functions that the compiler can verify are side-effect-free and referentially transparent , which generally means that they 're easier to understand and less prone to bugs .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O B-Application O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: It 's possible to write side-effect-free code in other languages , but you do n't have the compiler 's help in doing so .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Application O O O O O O

sentence: Haskell makes you think more carefully about which parts of your program need to have side effects ( such as I/O or mutable variables ) and which parts should be pure .
tag_sequence: B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Type O B-Data_Type O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Also , although it 's not quite part of the type system itself , the fact that function definitions in Haskell are expressions ( rather than lists of statements ) means that more of the code is subject to type-checking .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In languages like C++ and Java , it 's often possible to introduce logic errors by writing statements in the wrong order , since the compiler does n't have a way to determine that one statement must precede another .
tag_sequence: O O O B-Language O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Application O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For example , you might have one line that modifies an object 's state , and another line that does something important based on that state , and it 's up to you to ensure that these things happen in the correct order .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In Haskell , this kind of ordering dependency tends to be expressed through function composition — e.g . f ( g x ) means that g must run first — and the compiler can check the return type of g against the argument type of f to make sure you have n't composed them the wrong way .

sentence: Caching System.Drawing objects is a mistake .
tag_sequence: O B-Library_Class O O O O O

sentence: They are very cheap to create , very expensive to keep around .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: They are allocated on a special heap that all processes on a desktop need to share .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O B-Data_Structure O O O O O B-Device O O O O

sentence: The heap size is limited to 65535 objects .
tag_sequence: O B-Data_Structure O O O O O O O

sentence: Creating objects like a brush or a pen takes roughly a microsecond , miniscule compared to the cost of the operation you perform with them .
tag_sequence: O O O O B-Library_Class O O B-Library_Class O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The only drawing object that is expensive is a Font .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O B-Library_Class O

sentence: Creating one involves a sizable chunk of overhead taken by the font mapper .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O B-Library_Class O O

sentence: But that 's already solved by .NET , it caches them .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O B-Library O O O O O

sentence: Other than hogging the heap needlessly , the programming style is dangerous .
tag_sequence: O O O O B-Data_Structure O O O O O O O O

sentence: It is far too easy to forget blindly applying the using statement .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: This certainly can get you into trouble , you are relying on the finalizer thread to release them again .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If a program involves lots of heavy painting but not enough object allocation to trigger a GC then you will exhaust the quota for GDI objects .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Library O O

sentence: Which is 10,000 objects for a process by default .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: This will crash your program .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O

sentence: Do note that the System.Drawing class wrappers are not nearly big enough to trigger a GC by themselves , 10000 of them will not be enough to get the finalizers to run and release the handles again .

sentence: When designing my software , I began with interfaces since this seems to be the " standard " .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Then I switched to abstract classes because they seem better suited to the problem at hand .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: However I 'm not sure if I 've missed out on some considerations when making this design choice .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Other than domain specific issues which I have thought about what are the more general factors to consider when choosing between interfaces and abstracts classes ?
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If your interface also has reasonable default behavior for at least some of the functionality , you may want to use an abstract class to avoid common boilerplate code in all of the concrete implementations .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Otherwise , use an interface .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O

sentence: I find the best option most of the time is to do both .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: That is not always possible when you are relying on something happening in the base class .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Providing both an abstract base class and an interface allows the greatest latitude by implementers of your abstraction , again , as long as you do n't require something happens by an implementer of the interface .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If you require that something happens , then you do n't want to provide an interface at all--and you would also need to make sure that your base class ensures this required action to ALWAYS occur .. .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: You have a choice between thread confinement ( unfortunately , the default , which is obsolete ) , and queue confinement .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Structure O O

sentence: With thread confinement , you can only use a managed object context from the thread where it was created .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If you created your managed object context on the main thread ( or queue ) , you can only use it from there - so any Core Data operation you perform on that context will block the main thread , and in turn the UI .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Structure O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Library I-Library O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Using queue confinement ( almost ) any operation on the managed object context must go through either the performBlock : or performBlockAndWait : methods .

sentence: The enqueued block is executed on the context 's serial queue .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Structure O

sentence: This is far less failure prone than thread confinement and has been the recommended practice for concurrency since iOS 5 .

sentence: It does so by computing a near approximation of this and so you see a bit of error .

sentence: The extra digits come from the inherent errors caused by converting from binary to decimal .

sentence: You will not get rid of them .

sentence: The notion that it is bad practice for your UI to create/load/consume a datatable comes from the idea that it is preferable to split your application into layers that specialize , the most common split is to have 3 layers :

sentence: Layer 1 is a data layer responsible for communicating with the database and populating domain objects , the domain objects are typically defined in layer 2 which also holds the business logic for your application .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: by domain objects i mean classes that represent real things like customer , bank account , hotel room etc .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: and by business logic i mean the rules that apply to domain objects during events i.e . when a hotel room is booked a confirmation is sent to the customer .

sentence: the third layer is the UI layer , to simplyfy coding this should only deal with whats in layer 2 , this is where the recommendation to not use datatables in your UI comes from .

sentence: Typically the Memento pattern is used to implement roll-back/save point support .

sentence: The implementation of a Memento pattern could use serialisation , which would involve saving the contents of the object into a byte[] and keeping in memory or writing to disk .

sentence: When reverting the content of the object would be rebuilt from the serialised copy .

sentence: It works as a shared peripheral that provides an atomic test-and-test operation .

sentence: For instance , I ca n't see what precludes decision problems from being considered NP-hard optimization problems - if you consider , say , the MAX-CNF-SAT problem with the solutions being scored as floor(k/N) , where k is the number of satisfied clauses and N is the total number of clauses in the instance ( which is clearly computable in polynomial time ) , then any valuation which yields a 1 in this formula will have to satisfy the whole formula .
